questions.text: The distal convoluted tubules develop from which of the following structure?

A 10 year old boy was brought to the OPD with complaints of abdominal pain and vomiting. He has a history of frequent urinary infections. On CT scan, a horseshoe kidney was seen. Which of the following prevents the ascent of the organ?
While exposing the kidney from behind, all of the following nerves are liable to injury except
The trigone of the urinary bladder is derived from which structure

A 57-year-old man presents the urgent care clinic with a one-week history of diffuse bone pain and generalized weakness. He was diagnosed with end-stage renal disease 6 months ago and is currently on dialysis. His wife, who is accompanying him today, adds that he is not compliant with his medicines. He has been diabetic for the last 10 years and hypertensive for the last 7 years. He has smoked 4-5 cigarettes per day for 30 years but does not drink alcohol. His family history is insignificant. On examination, the patient has a waddling gait. Hypotonia of all the limbs is evident on neurologic examination. Diffuse bone tenderness is remarkable. X-ray of his legs reveal osteopenia and osseous resorption. The final step of activation of the deficient vitamin in this patient occurs by which of the following enzymes?

choices.text: Impaired distal tubule acidification in the kidneys
Decreased bicarbonate reabsorption in the proximal tubules

questions.text:
A 61 year old man presents to the emergency department with the complaints of nausea and muscle weakness for the past 24 hours. He was diagnosed with type II diabetes mellitus 20 years ago and hypertension 15 years ago for which he is taking metformin and captopril. Fingerstick blood glucose is 200 mg/dL. An ECG is ordered and shows peaked T waves
Lab studies show:
Blood pH - 732
Serum bicarbonate - 19 mEq/L Serum sodium - 135 mEq/L Serum chloride - 107 mEq/L Serum potassium - 6.5 mEq/L Urine anion gap - 20 meq/L
Which of the following is the primary defect responsible for this patient's condition?

choices.text: pH= 7.5, Pco2 = 50 mm Hg, Hco3 = 38 mEq/L
pH= 7.2, Pco2= 25 mm Hg, Hco3 = 30 mEq/L
pH= 75, Pco2 = 34 mm Hg, Hco3 = 38 mEq/L
pH = 72, Pco2= 55 mm Hg, Hco3 = 22 mEq/L

questions.text: A 22 year-old woman presents to her physician with complaints of cyclic vomiting for 3 days. The vomitus is watery and contains undigested food particles. She also complains of feeling tired and having the 'sniffles'. She has not felt like eating or drinking since her symptoms started, and she has not taken any medications. Her concern now is that she immediately gets dizzy when she stands up. Vitals signs include: pulse 120/min, respiratory rate 9/min, and blood pressure 100/70 mm Hg. Her eyes are sunken, and her tongue appears dry. Which set of lab values would best correspond to this patient's condition

choices.text: excretion rate of glucose equals the filtration rate of glucose
reabsorption rate of glucose equals the filtration rate of glucose
excretion rate of glucose increases with increasing plasma glucose concentrations

Secretion of K+ by the distal tubule will be decreased by

Following the incident, 16 men were admitted to the hospital, out of which, 3 were admitted in ICU due to their unstable condition. Which of the following is a likely finding in ABG in the admitted patients, who are not in ICU?
questions.solution: • Methanol Poisoning causes Metabolic Acidosis

Election micros-copy demonstrates permeation of the lamina dense of the GBM by a ribbon-like, homogenous, extremely electron-dese material of unknow composition
IgG is usually present however C1 and C4 are characteristically absent

What is the most commonly implicated antigen in neonatal membranous nephropathy?

questions.text: The resected specimen of a kidney is seen below. what is the diagnosis?

A 45 yr old male presented with complaints of difficulty in breathing. His ABG reports increased arterial blood pH and bicarbonate, arterial Pco2 in increased. History reveals he is taking a drug which increases his urine output for more than a year for some heart condition which he has. Which of the following drug has the least chance to produce this adverse effect in this patient

choices.text: Acute thiazide administration increases uric acid excretion
Thiazides decreases kidney's ability to excrete free water
Thiazide induced hypokalemia can be prevented by adding steroids

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding thiazide and thiazide like diuretics?
questions.solution:
• Acute thiazide administration increases uric acid excretion; however, uric acid excretion is reduced following chronic administration causing hyperuricemia
  • Thiazide diuretics causes magnesuria leading onto hypomagnesemia
  • Thiazides reduces kidney’s ability to excrete free water, increase proximal tubular water reabsorption and block the ability of DCT to form dilute urine. This is the reason why it is prescribed for nephrogenic diabetes insipidus
  • Amphotericin B and corticosteroids increase risk of hypokalemia by thiazide diuretics and in some cases (When given with quinidine, dofetilide, arsenic trioxide) might induce fatal ventricular arrhythmia.

questions.text: A 70 yr old woman was admitted in the emergency dept stating 'fainting spells' at home. On examination, her supine BP was 130/72mmHg and standing BP was 70/34mmHg. On questioning she reveals that she was taking some drug to increase her urine output for her cardiac condition. Which of the following drugs is most likely cause of her fainting spells
questions.solution: This is a case of syncope due to postural hypotension which is caused due to excessive reduction of blood volume. Among the answers given, the high ceiling diuretic (Furosemide) most commonly is associated with this adverse effect.

questions.text: An 85 yr old lady, under medication for heart failure, was given gentamicin for her diverticulitis. After few days of taking the antibiotic, she complaints of dizziness and tinnitus. What might be the medication involved in this interaction?
questions.solution: Loop diuretics (Esp, ethacrynic acid) is most associated with ototoxicity and when given along with gentamicin (Aminoglycoside), the chances of the patient landing up in dizziness and tinnitus is increased multi fold

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman presents with a 3-day duration of discomfort with urination and increased urinary frequency. She has noted that her urine has a strong odour as well. She denies fever, abdominal pain, back pain, vaginal discharge, or skin rash. On examination, she is comfortable appearing and afebrile. She has no costovertebral angle tenderness. Abdominal exam is notable only for suprapubic tenderness. Microscopic examination of the sediment of a centrifuged urine sample reveals 10-15 white blood cells per high power field and numerous bacteria. What is the most common etiologic agent of this infection?
questions.solution: Escherichia coli is the most commonly found aerobic, gram-negative bacilli in the GI tract of humans. Escherichia coli is responsible for over 80 percent of all urinary tract infections (UTIs), along with other clinical diseases including gastroenteritis, sepsis, and neonatal meningitis. The E.coli that causes diarrhea is usually acquired from the environment, whereas most other infections caused by E.coli are acquired endogenously.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man presents for a routine examination. He is generally feeling well but complains of some mild dysuria and increasing urinary frequency. He has not seen any blood in his urine but says that the urine does appear darker than it used to look. He has no other complaints and his review of systems is otherwise entirely negative. He has no significant medical or family history. He smokes a pack of cigarettes a day and denies alcohol use. His vital signs and physical examination, including genital and prostate exams, are normal. A urinalysis shows many red blood cells, a few white blood cells, and oval-shaped parasite eggs with terminal spines. What organism is the likely cause of his hematuria?
questions.solution: Schistosomiasis is a human disease syndrome caused by infection with one of several parasitic trematodes or flukes of the genus Schistosoma. These parasites are known commonly as blood flukes because the adult worms live in blood vessels of the definitive host. The human disease syndrome is characterized by dermatitis that is caused by entry of the infective stage and by acute and chronic systemic symptoms caused by host responses to eggs deposited by adult worms. Schistosoma haematobium, S.mansoni, and S.japonicum are the major species that infect over 200 million humans in Asia, Africa, the Middle East, and South America.

questions.text: A 77-year-old hospitalised male being treated successfully with vancomycin for hospital-acquired methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus bacteraemia develops a new onset of fever. A urinary tract infection is suspected and a Gram stain of unspun urine reveals neutrophils and Gram-positive cocci. Antibiotic sensitivity results of the organism cultured from the urine reveal resistance to cephalosporins, TMP-SMZ, aminoglycosides, and vancomycin. Which bacteria is the most likely cause of his urinary tract infection?
questions.solution: Enterococci are important causes of nosocomial urinary tract infections (UTIs). They are found as normal intestinal flora and cause disease when introduced into the body. UTI is the most common disease manifestation of this group. Enterococci are innately resistant to cephalosporins as this group of antibiotics cannot bind to enterococcal penicillin-binding proteins. Enterococci are able to utilise folic acid in their environment and are thus insensitive to TMP– SMZ. Although ampicillin plus an aminoglycoside is often used to treat enterococcal UTIs, these organisms show intrínsic resistance to aminoglycosides alone. Vancomycin resistance is the most alarming form of resistance among strains of enterococci as it is feared that the gene for this resistance could be shared among other species of bacteria, most notably, methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus.

questions.text: A 33-year-old woman with recently treated acute myelogenous leukemia now in remission is admitted to the hospital with lethargy, fever, and tachycardia. Blood cultures grow Pseudomonas that is resistant to cefepime. She is started on IV gentamicin. Five days after starting gentamicin, her serum creatinine rises from her baseline of 1.0mg/dL to 2.4mg/dL. No red or white cell casts are seen on her urinalysis. Her magnesium level is decreased at 1.5 mg/dL. Renal ultrasound is unremarkable with no hydronephrosis. Which of the following is the most likely mechanism of her acute kidney injury?
questions.solution: Several antimicrobial agents are commonly associated with AKI. Aminoglycosides (e.g., gentamicin) and amphotericin B both cause tubular necrosis. Nonoliguric AKI (i.e., with a urine volume >400 mL/day) accompanies 10–30% of courses of aminoglycoside antibiotics, even when plasma levels are in the therapeutic range. Aminoglycosides are freely filtered across the glomerulus and then accumulate within the renal cortex, where concentrations can greatly exceed those of the plasma. AKI typically manifests after 5–7 days of therapy and can present even after the drug has been discontinued. Hypomagnesemia is a common finding. AKI secondary to acute interstitial nephritis can occur as a consequence of exposure to many antibiotics, including penicillins, cephalosporins, quinolones, sulfonamides, and rifampin. There is no reason for ischemic injury by history. There are no red or white cell casts or anything in the history to suggest glomerulonephritis.

choices.text: Oral calcium supplement may be a risk factor
Warfarin is a risk factor for development of the lesion

questions.text: A 63-year-old woman with chronic kidney disease is maintained on daily peritoneal dialysis. Her past medical history is notable for hypertension and atrial fibrillation. Her medications include losartan and warfarin. Two days ago, she noticed a small painful nodule on her abdomen that has progressed to involve skin necrosis and ulceration of the abdominal wall. All of the following statements regarding her condition are true EXCEPT:
questions.solution: This patient has calciphylaxis. Calciphylaxis (calcific uremic arteriolopathy) is a devastating condition seen almost exclusively in patients with advanced chronic kidney disease. It is heralded by livedo reticularis and advances to patches of ischemic necrosis, especially on the legs, thighs, abdomen, and breasts. Pathologically, there is evidence of vascular occlusion in association with extensive vascular and soft tissue calcification. Many etiologies have been suggested, including the increased use of oral calcium as a phosphate binder. Warfarin is commonly used in hemodialysis patients, and one of the effects of warfarin therapy is to decrease the vitamin K–dependent regeneration of matrix GLA protein. The GLA protein is important in preventing vascular calcification. Thus, warfarin treatment is considered a risk factor for calciphylaxis, and if a patient develops this syndrome, this medication should be discontinued and replaced with alternative forms of anticoagulation. Pseudomonas bacteremia may cause ecthyma gangrenosum, which may have a necrotic plaque, typically in neutropenic patients.

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman undergoes a hysterectomy and postoperatively develops acute respiratory distress syndrome. She is treated with mechanical ventilation and broad-spectrum antibiotics. Aside from hypothyroidism, she has no underlying medical conditions. On day 5 of her hospitalization, her urine output is noted to fall, and her serum creatinine rises from 1.2 to 2.5 mg/dL. Allergic interstitial nephritis from cephalosporin antibiotics is suspected. Which of the following findings will 100% confirm this diagnosis
questions.solution: Allergic interstitial nephritis is a common cause of unexplained acute renal failure. This is generally a clinical diagnosis with acute renal failure in the context of exposure to a potential offending agent (often nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs, antibiotics, anticonvulsants, and proton pump inhibitors) and improvement in renal function with withdrawal of the agent. Peripheral blood eosinophilia supports the diagnosis but is rarely found. Urine microscopy often shows white blood cell casts and hematuria, but these are not specific findings. Urine eosinophils are neither sensitive nor specific for allergic interstitial nephritis. A renal biopsy is generally not required, but may show extensive tubulointerstitial infiltration of white cells including eosinophils. Discontinuation of the offending agent often leads to reversal of the renal injury. Glucocorticoid therapy may accelerate renal recovery but does not appear to impact long-term renal survival.

questions.text: Eculizumab, used in the treatment of atypical hemolytic uremic syndrome, targets which of the following?
questions.solution: Atypical hemolytic-uremic syndrome (HUS) or complement- mediated HUS is the result of complement dysregulation. The complement dysregulation can be congenital or acquired. The affected patients often have a low C3 and normal C4 levels characteristic of alternative pathway activation. Factor H deficiency, the most common defect. Eculizumab is a monoclonal antibody to C5 that is approved for use in aHUS, which has been shown to abort microangiopathic hemolyticanemia and improve renal function

questions.text: A 66-year-old woman presents to the emergency room with malaise, confusion, and headache. Blood pressure is found to be 220/105. Physical examination is notable for skin thickening of the arms and legs, facial telangiectasias, and decreased oral aperture. Laboratory studies show a creatinine of 3.5 mg/dL, hemoglobin of 7.0 g/dL, platelets of 75,000/dL, lactate dehydrogenase of 700. What is the appropriate initial treatment?
questions.solution: Scleroderma renal crisis occurs in 12% of patients with diffuse systemic sclerosis but in only 2% of those with limited systemic sclerosis. Scleroderma renal crisis is the most severe manifestation of renal involvement, and it is characterized by accelerated hypertension, a rapid decline in renal function, nephrotic range proteinuria, and hematuria. Retinopathy and encephalopathy may accompany the hypertension. Salt and water retention with microvascular injury can lead to pulmonary edema. Cardiac manifestations, including myocarditis, pericarditis, and arrhythmias, denote an especially poor prognosis. The renal lesion in scleroderma renal crisis is characterized by arcuate artery intimal and medial proliferation with luminal narrowing. Before the availability of ACE inhibitors, the mortality rate for scleroderma renal crisis was >90% at 1 month. Introduction of renin-angiotensin system blockade has lowered the mortality rate to 30% at 3 years. Nearly two-thirds of patients with scleroderma renal crisis may require dialysis support, with recovery of renal function in 50% (median time, 1 year). Treatment with ACE inhibition is the first-line therapy unless contraindicated. Both ACE inhibitors and angiotensin II receptor antagonists are effective, although data suggest that treatment with ACE inhibitors is superior.

choices.text: A 30-year-old man with an estimated GFR of 50 mL/min/1.73 m2 and 350 mg/g of persistent albuminuria
A 45-year-old man with an estimated GFR of 90 mL/min/1.73 m2 and <30 mg/g of persistent albuminuria
A 55-year-old man with an estimated GFR of 70 mL/min/1.73 m2 and 100 mg/g of persistent albuminuria
A 65-year-old woman with an estimated GFR of 65 mL/min/1.73 m2 and <30 mg/g of persistent albuminuria

questions.text: Which of the following patients has the greatest risk of progression to chronic kidney disease
questions.solution: CKD encompasses a spectrum of different pathophysiologic processes associated with abnormal kidney function and a progressive decline in GFR. Stages of CKD are stratified by both estimated GFR and the degree of albuminuria to predict risk of progression of CKD. Previously, CKD had been staged solely by the GFR. However, the risk of worsening of kidney function is closely linked to the amount of albuminuria, so it has been incorporated into the classification. Note that although age impacts GFR, it is not an independent criterion for risk of progression to CKD. CKD is still staged by GFR. GFR is ≥90 mL/min/1.73 m2 in stage I, 60–89 mL/ min/1.73 m2 in stage II, 30–59 mL/min/1.73 m2 in stage III, 15–29 mL/min/1.73 m2 in stage IV, and <15 mL/min/1.73 m2 in stage V.

questions.text: A patient has both lower extremities crushed after being hit by a car. On admission, the patient is restless and is complaining of pain in both legs. His blood pressure is 130/80 mm Hg and his heart rate is 90 beats per minute. Abdominal and chest x-rays are normal. Both thighs are swollen and both femurs are obviously fractured. Urinalysis reveals massive hemoglobinuria. What is the next appropriate step in his management
questions.solution: Vigorous hydration with isotonic crystalloid is the cornerstone of rhabdomyolysis treatment. Because injured myocytes tend to sequester a lot of fluid, fluids should be administered liberally. Urinary alkalinization to prevent acute renal failure is supported by literature. This may be combined with mannitol once the patient has been resuscitated. Loop diuretics should only be used once the patient has been hydrated. Hyperkalemia does occur and may need to be treated with glucose and insulin

questions.text: A Chronic Kidney disease patient was brought to the casualty with worsening of breathlessness along with decreased urine output. ECG showed the following finding. Which of the following drugs should be given for this patient urgently:
questions.solution: This ECG finding of sine wave pattern in a CKD patient with probable recent worsening is most likely associated with hyperkalemia. Hence calcium gluconate has to be given urgently

questions.text: Which of the findings does not favor pre-renal azotemia ?
questions.solution: In pre-renal azotemia, Fractional excretion of sodium is <1%

questions.text: The best therapy for hepatorenal syndrome is :
questions.solution:
HEPATORENAL SYNDROME (HRS)

  • Serum creatinine level doubles to a value higher than 2.5 mg/dL in a period of 2 weeks or less.
  • Characterized by a rapidly progressive form of renal dysfunction.
  • Type 1 HRS
  • HRS is classified into two types based on clinical characteristics and prognosis.
  • Form of functional renal failure without renal pathology in patients with advanced cirrhosis or acute liver failure.
  • Type 2 HRS
  • More slowly progressive and has better outcome than type 1 HRS
  • Serum creatinine levels are less than 2.5 mg/dl.
  • TREATMENT OF HRS
  • In the past, dopamine or prostaglandin analogues were used as renal vasodilating medications.
  • Currently, patients are treated with midodrine, an α-agonist, along with octreotide and intravenous albumin.
  • The best therapy for HRS is liver transplantation; recovery of renal function is typical in this setting. In patients with either type 1 or type 2 HRS, the prognosis is poor unless transplant can be achieved within a short period of time.

questions.text: The image below shows the urine examination finding in a 45 year old male admitted to the nephrology ward. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: The presence of 'muddy brown casts' of epithelial cells found in the urine during urinalysis is pathognomonic for Acute tubular necrosis

questions.text: A 33-year-old previously healthy woman presents to the emergency department with malaise, confusion, and fever of 37.8°C. She had no preceding diarrheal illness. CT of the head is unremarkable. She is found to have platelets of 13,000/mm3, Hb of 9.0 g/dL, and creatinine of 2.3 mg/dL. Urinalysis shows pH 5.0, protein 1+, and 11 RBCs/hpf. Which of the following laboratory findings would be expected with her diagnosis?
questions.solution: Thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP) and hemolyticuremic syndrome (HUS) represent a spectrum of thrombotic microangiopathies. TTP and HUS share the general features of idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura, microangiopathic hemolyticanemia, fever, renal failure, and neurologic disturbances. When patients, particularly children, have more evidence of renal injury, their condition tends to be called HUS. In adults with neurologic disease, it is considered to be TTP. In adults there is often a mixture of both, which is why they are often referred to as having TTP/HUS. In familial cases of adult TTP/HUS, there is a genetic deficiency of the ADAMTS13 metalloprotease that cleaves large multimers of von Willebrand factor.

questions.text: Management of 4cm size renal stag horn calculus?(AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
• Latest treatment of such 4cm size Stag horn stone is “Sandwich technique”- Using both ESWL and PCNL. They will break the stone into multiple pieces before and remove by PCNL.

(Ref. Smith Urology page 114/ 17th edition, Surgery Sixer 2nd Edition Page 735 repeat question

questions.text: A 35 yrs old male came to hospital with dysuria and pus cells on examination. Culture came negative. After few hours patient expired. Autopsy of kidney as follows.(JIPMER Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
• Most common site of genitourinary tuberculosis is – Kidney
  • Genitourinary tuberculosis is always secondary to pulmonary infection, though in many cases has healed or is quiescent.
  • Infection occurs via the hematogenous route.
  • Most sensitive modality to detect Early TB- IVP (Blunting of Calyx)

Advanced changes in kidney and ureter:

  • Calcification
  • Cavities
  • Fibrosis leading to obstruction
  • Fibrotic strictures of the pelvis or ureters lead to hydronephrosis
  • Strictures of the calyceal neck leads to hydrocalyces (or hydrocalicosis)

Bladder changes

  • Bladder wall may appear thickened and trabeculated and bladder may be small, contracted. (thimble bladder**)
  • In later stages VUR my develop

Investigations for TB Renal Tract:

  • “Sterile pyuria is the rule in renal TB
  • The tubercle bacilli can be identified on AFB staining of 24 hr urine specimen or the first morning urine collected on 3 successive days. ‘ AFB staining is positive in about 60% of cases.

Recent advance:

  • Computed tomography : shows advanced changes in Renal TB well but is less sensitive in early stages as it cannot detailed calyceal anatomy.
  • For Early changes IVP is best. IVP is replaced by CT urography recently to detect the earliest changes in TB

Ref. Bailey and Love 26th edition Page 1303

questions.text: In complete duplication of ureters Proximal segment?(JIPMER Nov 2017 Pattern)
questions.solution:
• Ectopic ureters are usually associated with duplicate ureters (in 80% cases) but may also occur in single ureters systems
  • More common in females**
  • In the male, the posterior urethra is the most common site of termination of an ectopic ureter.

Weigert - Meyer rule of Ectopic ureters:

  • Weigert Meyer rule states that upper pole ureter is the ectopic ureter and its orifice inserts infero medially in bladder in relationship to the lower pole normal ureter.
  • The ureter of the upper pole moiety obstructs.The upper pole ureter is usually obstructed resulting in ureterocele and forms hydronephrosis of corresponding renal pelvis.
  • The ureter of the lower pole moiety refluxes. The lower pole ureter reluxes at its level often causes pyelonephritis**
  • In a male patients the ectopic ureters opens always above the external urethral sphincter (the bulbar urethra is below the external urethral sphincter)
  • In females patient ectopic ureters may open above or below the external urethral sphincter

Most common symptom

  • In males- recurrent UTI
  • In females- incontinence (paradoxical incontinence)
  • Ectopic opening below the external urethral sphincter leads to urinary incontinence: “continuous incontinence in a girl with an otherwise normal voiding pattern after toilet training is the classic symptom of an ectopic ureteral orifice”
  • Treatment : Reimplantation of ureter is done, if kidney is scarred

(Ref. Bailey and Love 26th edition Page 1286

questions.text: Sickle cell anaemia is associated with which type of RCC(JIPMER Nov 2017 Pattern)
questions.solution:
Cytogenetics of various subtypes of Renal Cell Ca

MC type Clear cell RCC

MC type seen in Dialysis associated cystic disease- Papillary RCC

MC type seen in sickle cell trait- Medullary RCC

Best prognosis- Chromophobe RCC

Clear cell carcinoma

  • Is the most common type(70-80)
  • These tumors can be
    • Familial
    • Associated with VHL disease or
    • Sporadic (95%)
  • Almost all (-98%) of clear cell carcinomas are associated with loss of sequences on short arm of chromosome 3. The lost sequences include the VHL gene.
  • The VHL gene acts as tumor-suppressor gene the loss of which is associated with clear cell Cancer

Papillary carcinoma

  • Also occurs in both familial and sporadic forms
  • The cytogenetic abnormalities associated with papillary Ca are

questions.text: In Radical Nephrectomy the following structures are resected except (Recent pattern 2017)
questions.solution:
Classical Radical Nephrectomy consists of removal of following structures:

  • Kidney
  • Peri renal Fat
  • Adrenal Gland
  • Reginal Lymph nodes

Notable points:

  • If tumor is <5 cm and present in Inferior pole- Adrenal gland can be spared
  • Regional node dissection done for cases in which nodes detected by CT scan or during Surgical Procedure.
  • Stage 1 and 2 can be operated by Laparoscopic procedure.
  • Renal Vein and IVC involvement are still operable candidates, IVC tumor thrombus must be removed with help of CTVS surgeons.

Cytoreductive nephrectomy:

  • Inoperable metastatic disease also we can do cytoreductive surgery so that medial survival is prolonged.

Partial nephrectomy for RCC:

  • Indicated for T1 tumors .
  • Also indicated for VHL patients having Bilateral tumors, or patients with only one kidney or patients with impaired renal function.
  • Relative Indications- Hypertension, Diabetes, Pyelonephritis
  • Nephrometry Scoring Systems like R.E.N.A.L or PADUA scoring systems are used to predict the partial nephrectomy procedures.
  • Hematuria, Perirenal hematoma and Urinary fistula are most common complications

questions.text: Harder Stone with less satisfactory result in ESWL is (Recent Pattern 2017)
questions.solution:
Extra Corporeal Shock Wave Lithotripsy:

  • Shock waves generated and focused on the stones.
  • Methods of Shock Wave Generation:
    • Spark Gap
    • Electromagnetic
    • Piezo Electric
    • Micro Expulsive
  • Cardiac arrhythmias can happen in cases of Spark Gap generated waves***.
  • ESWL is indicated for stones upto 1.5 cm in kidney
  • Prophylactic antibiotics are advised.
  • Relatively resistant stone is CYSTINE ** due to its hardness.
  • Contraindications: Pregnancy and Oral Anticoagulant drug consuming patients
  • Steinstrasse”- Stone street is collection of stone fragments in distal ureter after breaking by ESWL.

Ref. Bailey and Love 27th edition Page 1408

questions.text: Pure Radiolucent stone (Recent Pattern 2017)
questions.solution:
Radiolucent Kidney Stones:

  • Pure Uric Acid Stones
  • Xanthine
  • Indinavir Drug induced Stone

Uric Acid Stone:

  • 5-10% of all stones
  • Seen in Excessive acid urine( pH<5.5)
  • Uric acid is an end product of Purine metabolism
  • Dietary protein and Protein excess results in increased urinary URIC acid and stone.
  • Myeloproliferative diseases, Chemotherapy drugs induce this stone.
  • Uric acid stone is also formed in Normal Uric acid level.
  • Low urine volume like in IBD, Ileostomies may also stimulate Uric acid Stone.
  • Stones are hard, multifaceted, multiple.
  • Pure Uric Acid Stones are Radiolucent.

questions.text: 40 years old male complaints of recurrent UTI, X ray KUB Shows Radio opaque shadow Diagnosis (Recent Pattern 2017)
questions.solution:
• Ureteric Pathology is associated with UTI and Hematuria*
  • Usually radio opaque and seen on KUB Xray
  • IOC is CT KUB plain, detects 99% of the stones in ureter.
  • Stones less than 5 mm will pass out.

Ref. Bailey 27th edition Page 1408

questions.text: MC type of Renal Cancer(Recent Pattern 2017)
questions.solution:
Renal Cell cancer:

  • Tumors arise from Renal Tubular Epithelial cells
  • Male: Female ratio= 2:1
  • 2% of all cancers diagnosis and deaths
  • Subtypes are:
    • Clear cell RCC- Most common Subtype**
    • Papillary RCC
    • Chromophobe RCC
  • If cancer is diagnosed in age <46 years: possibility of an underlying hereditary cancer syndrome is considered. Incidence of this type is 3-5%.
  • Classic Triad: Loin pain, Mass, Hematuria** is seen in <10% cases

choices.text: Incidence during pregnancy is similar to that in non-pregnant women
Universal screening for bacteriuria is recommended at the first prenatal visit
Urinary tract infection increases the risk of preterm delivery
Antimicrobial therapy does not improve the pregnancy outcome and is not recommended

questions.text: All of the following are true about asymptomatic bacteriuria except?
questions.solution:
Incidence of asymptomatic bacteriuria during pregnancy is similar to that in non-pregnant women(2 to 7%)

It is more common in diabetics

ACOG recommends Universal screening for bacteriuria at the first prenatal visit

Urinary tract infection increases the risk of preterm delivery, low birth weight, hypertension and anemia

Antimicrobial therapy is recommended to improve pregnancy outcomes

Recurrence rate is 30%

questions.text: All of the following are included in the ambit of complicated relapse in pediatric nephrotic syndrome, except?
questions.solution:
According to the latest ISPN guidelines, Complicated Relapse is defined as: Any Relapse associated with life-threatening complications like

  1. Hypovolemia requiring inpatient care
  2. Severe infection (peritonitis, cellulitis, meningitis)
  3. Thrombosis

choices.text: Recurrent UTI is a common consequence
MCU preferred for initial diagnosis over radionuclide studies
No role of antibiotic prophylaxis in infants with VUR

questions.text: Identify the incorrect statement regarding Vesicoureteric reflux?
questions.solution:
Points to remember

  • VUR shows autosomal dominant inheritance with incomplete penetrance
  • More common in females
  • Recurrent UTI and reflux nephropathy occur due to VUR
  • MCU is initial IOC due to better anatomic details and to determine grade of VUR
  • Antibiotic prophylaxis indicated in all initial cases, esp infants in whom febrile UTIs are esp common
  • Surgery indicated in breakthrough UTI and persistent bladder abnormalities

choices.text: Females more commonly affected than males

questions.text: Look at the given image and tell the unlikely finding in this child?
questions.solution:
The child has Prune-Belly Syndrome/Eagle-Barrett Syndrome

Characterized by a triad of

  • Lax/Wrinkled lower abdominal wall
  • Bilateral undescended testes
  • Dilated abnormal urinary tract, including the bladder

More common in males

Associated anomalies include Pulmonary hypoplasia, DDH, Pectus excavatum, VUR Rx is primarily surgical

questions.text: An infant presented to a clinic with complaints of failure to thrive. On evaluation, the child had normal BP, hypercalciuria and metabolic alkalosis. What is the likely cause?
questions.solution: The Flow-Chart To Remember

questions.text: 22-year-old women presents to the emergency department with a chief complaint of severe left upper quadrant(LUQ) pain after bring punched by her husband. Her blood pressure is 110/76, her pulse is 80 bpm, and her respiration rate is 24 breaths per minute. The best means to establish a diagnosis is which of the following?
questions.solution:
• Clinical picture of the patient in above question indicates that patient is hemodynamically stable. Therefore best mode of evaluation should be CT scan of abdomen to seen the extent of injury
  • Investigations in abdominal trauma is CECT
  • If the patient is hemodynamically stable and can be shifted CECT scan
  • If the patients is hemodynamically unstable and cannot be shifted-ultrasound

questions.text: A Young Female with Hypertension Shows the following angiographic findings, Probable Diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
• Fibromuscular dysplasia is a characterised by an idiopathic, non-inflammatory,non-atherosclerotic angiopathy of small and medium-sized arteries.
  • More common in young women, typically diagnosed between the ages of 30 and 50
